injected cocaine to crack cocaine use may have also slowed the spread of disease.<ref name=MacQueen2012/> Rates of HIV infection dropped from 8.1 cases per 100 person-years in 1997 to 0.37 cases per 100 person-years by 2011.<ref name="UHRI2013"/> By 2015, the 40-block area surrounding the safe injection site had a 35% decline in overdose deaths.<ref name = MacQueen2015/> [[File:Crack Cocaine Smokers in Vancouver Alleyway.jpg|thumb|left|alt=refer to caption|Crack cocaine use in a DTES alley]] In the 21st century, considerable investment was made in DTES services and infrastructure, including the redevelopment of the [[Woodward's Building]] and the acquisition of 23 SRO hotels by the provincial government for conversion to social housing.<ref name=Morton2015/> In 2009, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' estimated that governments and the private sector had spent more than $1.4 billion since 2000 on projects aimed at resolving the area's many problems.<ref name=Matas2009>{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Matas |title=The Money Pit |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/incoming/the-money-pit/article1148807/?page=all |work=The Globe and Mail | place=Toronto|publisher= |date=13 February 2009 |accessdate=3 September 2015}}</ref>
Opinions vary on whether the area has improved: A 2014 article in the ''[[National Post]]'' said, "For all the money and attention here, there is little success at either getting the area's shattered populace back on their feet, or cleaning up the neighbourhood into something resembling a healthy community."<ref name="Hopper2014">{{cite news|last1=Hopper|first1=Tristin|title=Vancouver's ‘gulag’: Canada's poorest neighbourhood refuses to get better despite $1M a day in social spending|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/vancouvers-gulag-canadas-poorest-neighbourhood-refuses-to-get-better-despite-1m-a-day-in-social-spending|accessdate=6 April 2016|work=National Post| place=Toronto|date=14 November 2014}}</ref> Former [[New Democratic Party|NDP]] premier [[Mike Harcourt]] described the current reality of the neighbourhood as "100-per-cent failure."<ref name="Quinn2014">{{cite news|last1=Quinn|first1=Stephen|title=Downtown Eastside redevelopment debate is the same old game|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/downtown-eastside-redevelopment-debate-is-the-same-old-game/article17505903/|accessdate=25 August 2016|work=The Globe and Mail|date=14 March 2014}}</ref> Also in 2014, B.C. housing minister [[Rich Coleman]] said, "I’ll go down for a walk in the Downtown Eastside, night time or day time, and it's dramatically different than it was. It's incredibly better than it was five, six years ago."<ref name=Culbert2014/>
==Demographics== [[File:Womens housing march vancouver 2012.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Aboriginal demonstrators at a march for Women's Housing in the DTES|Demonstrators at a march for women's housing, part of the long history of social activism in the DTES]] There are no official population figures for the DTES. Estimates have ranged from 6,000<ref name=Matas2009/> to 8,000;<ref name="Douglas 2002, chapter 1"/> the geographic boundaries associated with these figures was not provided.
Official figures are available for the greater DTES area, which was home to an estimated 18,477 people in 2011.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=6}} In comparison to the city of Vancouver overall, the greater DTES had a higher proportion of males (60% vs. 50%), more seniors (22% vs 13%), fewer children and youth (10% vs 18%), slightly fewer immigrants, and more [[Aboriginal Canadian|Aboriginals]] (10% vs. 2%).{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=10}}
A 2009 demographic profile by ''The Globe and Mail'' focused on an area of just over 30 city blocks in and around the DTES: It indicated that 14% of the residents were of Aboriginal descent.<ref name = "Globe and Mail">{{cite web |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/incoming/exclusive-demographic-picture/article4277604/|title= Exclusive demographic picture: A comparison of key statistics in the DTES, Vancouver, B.C. and Canada|accessdate=3 September 2015 |author= Patrick Brethour|date= 13 February 2009|work= Globe and Mail |place=Toronto}}</ref> The average household size was 1.3 residents; 82% of the population lived alone. Children and teenagers made up 7% of the population, compared to 25% for Canada overall.<ref name = "Globe and Mail"/>
A population that is frequently studied is tenants of single room occupancy (SRO) hotels in the greater DTES area. According to a 2013 survey, this population is 77% male, with a median age of 44. Aboriginals make up 28% of the population, and Europeans 59%.<ref name="Vila-Rodriguez2013">{{cite journal |last=Vila-Rodriguez |first=Fidel |last2=Panenka |first2=William J. |date= 1 December 2003 |title=The Hotel Study: Multimorbidity in a Community Sample Living in Marginal Housing |url= http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/doi/abs/10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.12111439 |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |publisher= |volume=170 |issue=12 |pages=1413–1422 |doi= 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.12111439|pmid=23929175 |access-date=23 August 2016}}</ref>
==Current issues==
===Addiction and mental illness=== {{wide image | 2014 - Vancouver - Went to Sleep with 2 Red Pumps, Woke up with 1 (15029636797).jpg |500px|alt=Photograph of a disheveled man sitting amidst shopping carts and junk|A man rests on the sidewalk near Hastings and Gore |45%| left }} The DTES population suffers from very high rates of [[mental illness]] and [[addiction]]. In 2007, [[Vancouver Coastal Health]] estimated that 2,100 DTES residents "exhibit behaviour that is outside the norm" and require more support in the areas of health and addiction services.{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=36}} According to the [[Vancouver Police Department]] (VPD) in 2008, up to 500 of these individuals were "chronically mentally ill with disabling addictions, extreme behaviours, no permanent housing and regular police contact."{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=54}} As of 2009, the DTES was home to an estimated 1,800 to 3,600 individuals who were considered to be at "extremely high health risk" due to severe addiction and/or mental illness, equivalent to 60% of the population in this category for the 1 million people in the Vancouver Coastal Health region.<ref name="VCH2013">{{cite web|last1=Regional Mental Health & Addiction Program|title=Improving health outcomes, housing and safety: Addressing the needs of individuals with severe addiction and mental illness|url=http://www.health.gov.bc.ca/library/publications/year/2013/improving-severe-addiction-and-mental-illness-services.pdf|publisher=Vancouver Coastal Health|accessdate=16 April 2016|date=November 2013}}</ref>
A 2013 study of SRO tenants in the greater DTES found that 95.2% had some form of substance dependence and 74.4% had a mental illness, including 47.4% with psychosis.<ref name="Vila-Rodriguez2013"/> Only one third of individuals with psychosis were receiving treatment, and among those with concurrent addiction, the proportion receiving treatment was even lower.<ref name="Vila-Rodriguez2013"/> A 2016 study of the 323 most chronic offenders in the DTES found that 99% had at least one mental disorder, and more than 80% also had substance abuse issues.<ref name="Woo2016">{{cite news|last1=Woo|first1=Andrea|title=Vancouver subset struggling to escape corrections system's ‘revolving door,’ study says|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/vancouver-subset-struggling-to-escape-corrections-systems-revolving-door-study-says/article28046243/|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=6 Jan 2016}}</ref> Between 60% and 70% of mentally ill patients treated at [[St. Paul's Hospital (Vancouver)|St. Paul's Hospital]], the hospital closest to the DTES, are estimated to have multiple addictions.{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=22}} Possible explanations for the high level of [[dual diagnosis|co-occurrence]] between addiction and mental illness in the DTES include the vulnerability of the mentally ill to drug dealers, and a recent rise in [[crystal methamphetamine]] use, which can cause permanent [[psychosis]].<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 13"/><ref name="Luk2013">{{cite news|last1=Luk|first1=Vivian|title=How drugs, lack of safe housing fuel Vancouver's mental-health crisis|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/how-drugs-lack-of-safe-housing-fuel-vancouvers-mental-health-crisis/article14853847/|accessdate=6 April 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=13 October 2013}}</ref>
====Substance use==== [[File:April, With Intriguing Books and Suffering Withdrawal.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Photograph of a woman with facial lesions, sitting on the sidewalk|A person who uses drugs, seen on Hastings Street]] A 2010 [[BBC]] article described the DTES as "home to one of the worst drug problems in North America."<ref name="BBC2010">{{cite news|last1=Mirchandani|first1=Rajesh|title=Vancouver: 'Drug Central' of North America|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8505061.stm|accessdate=4 April 2016|publisher=BBC|date=10 February 2010}}</ref> In 2011, [[crack cocaine]] was the most commonly used illicit [[Drug harmfulness|hard drug]] in Vancouver, followed by injected prescription opioids (such as [[fentanyl]] and [[OxyContin]]), [[heroin]], [[crystal methamphetamine]] (usually injected rather than smoked), and [[cocaine]] (also usually injected).<ref name=UHRI2013/> Alcoholism, especially when it involves the use of highly toxic isopropyl alcohol, is a significant source of harm to residents of the DTES.<ref name=VCH2015/>
In 2016, a board member of the [[Vancouver Area Network of Drug Users]] said that in the previous year, Vancouver's supply of heroin had virtually disappeared and been replaced by fentanyl, which is cheaper and more potent.<ref name="Geordon2016">{{cite news|last1=Geordon|first1=Omand|title=Little if any heroin left in Vancouver, all fentanyl: drug advocates|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/little-if-any-heroin-left-in-vancouver-all-fentanyl-drug-advocates|accessdate=24 May 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=22 May 2016}}</ref> At the end of 2014, the DTES saw a dramatic rise in fentanyl overdoses. In 2016 the surge in drug overdose deaths led to the declaration of a public health emergency across the province.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ellis|first1=Erin and Bethany Lindsay|title=B.C. declares public health emergency after fentanyl overdoses|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/b-c-declares-public-health-emergency-after-fentanyl-overdoses|work=Vancouver Sun|date=14 April 2016}}</ref>
In a 2008 survey of SRO residents in the greater DTES, 32% self-reported as being addicted to drugs, 20% were addicted to alcohol, 52% smoked cigarettes regularly, and 51% smoked marijuana.<ref name=Lewis2008/> In 2003, the DTES was home to an estimated 4,700 injection drug users.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=91}} Most live in unstable housing or are homeless,{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=91}} and approximately 20% are sex workers.<ref name="UHRI2013">{{cite web|title=Drug Situation in Vancouver, 2nd Edition|url=http://www.cfenet.ubc.ca/sites/default/files/uploads/news/releases/war_on_drugs_failing_to_limit_drug_use.pdf|website=British Columbia Centre of Excellence in HIV/AIDS|publisher=Urban Health Research Initiative of the British Columbia Centre for Excellence in HIV/AIDS|accessdate=4 April 2016 }}</ref> In 2006, DTES residents incurred half of the deaths from illegal drug overdoses in the entire province.<ref name="BCMA2009">{{cite web|title=Stepping Forward – Improving Addiction Care in British Columbia|url=https://www.doctorsofbc.ca/sites/default/files/addiction_stepping_forward.pdf|publisher=British Columbia Medical Association|accessdate=11 April 2016|date=March 2009}}</ref> Between 1996 and 2011, there have been large fluctuations in drug usage, with the most recent trend being an overall decline in illicit drug use between 2007 and 2011.<ref name=UHRI2013/> However, between 2010 and 2014, hospitalizations related to addictions increased by 89% at St. Paul's Hospital.<ref name=Katic2014/>
According to a 2008 survey of greater DTES area SROs, tenants who used drugs estimated the cost of their habits at $30 per day, on average.<ref name="Lewis2008">{{cite web|author1=Martha Lewis|author2=Kathleen Boyes|author3=Dale McClanaghan|author4=Jason Copas|title=Downtown Eastside Demographic Study of SRO and Social Housing Tenants|url=http://www.vancouveragreement.ca/wp-content/uploads/080600_DTES-Demographic-Study-Final.pdf|publisher=Vancouver Agreement|accessdate=12 May 2016|format=PDF|date=April 2008}}</ref> Some spend hundreds of dollars per day on drugs.<ref name="Matas2012">{{cite news|last1=Matas|first1=Robert|title=Tackling chronic offenders key to reducing Vancouver's high crime rates|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/tackling-chronic-offenders-key-to-reducing-vancouvers-high-crime-rates/article1359244/|accessdate=22 May 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=6 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="Krishnan2016">{{cite news|last1=Krishnan|first1=Manisha|title=We Asked Drug Addicts How Much Their Habit Costs Them|url=https://www.vice.com/read/the-cost-of-being-a-drug-addict-in-canada|accessdate=6 June 2016|work=Vice|date=8 March 2016}}</ref> Police attribute much of the [[property crime]] in Vancouver to chronic repeat offenders who steal to support their drug habits.<ref name=Matas2012/>
====Mental illness==== The VPD reported in 2008 that in its district that includes the Downtown Eastside, mental health was a factor in 42% of all incidents in which police were involved.{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=12}} The police department says its officers are often forced to act as front-line mental health workers, due to the lack of more appropriate supports for this population.{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=2}}
In 2013, the city and police department reported that in the previous three years, there had been a 43% increase in people with severe mental illness and/or addiction in the emergency department of St. Paul's Hospital. In Vancouver, apprehensions under the ''Mental Health Act'' rose by 16% between 2010 and 2012, and there was also an increase in the number of violent incidents involving mentally ill people.<ref name=Cole2013>{{cite news|last1=Cole|first1=Yolande|title=Vancouver police and mayor issue recommendations to address mental health "crisis"|url=https://www.straight.com/news/424456/vancouver-police-and-mayor-issue-recommendations-address-mental-health-crisis|accessdate=5 April 2016|work= Georgia Straight| place=Vancouver|date=13 September 2013}}</ref> Mayor [[Gregor Robertson (politician)|Gregor Robertson]] described the mental health crisis as "on par with, if not more serious than" the DTES HIV/AIDS epidemic that had led to a declaration of a public health emergency in 1997.<ref name=Cole2013/>
===Sex Work=== {{See also|Prostitution in Canada}} {{Reduced pull quote |right | In my 12 years of work as a physician in the DTES, I never met a female patient who had not been sexually abused as a child or adolescent, nor a male who had not suffered some form of severe trauma... Addictions are attempts to escape pain. | [[Gabor Maté (physician)|Gabor Maté]]|<ref name="Mate2016">{{cite news|last1=Maté|first1=Gabor|title=Opinion: Health-care system poorly understands our addicts and mentally ill|url=http://vancouversun.com/opinion/opinion-health-care-system-poorly-understands-our-addicts-and-mentally-ill|accessdate=12 April 2016|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=24 January 2016}}</ref>}} Vancouver has an estimated 1,000 street sex workers<ref name="Dobell2007">{{cite web|last1=Dobell Advisory Services Inc and DCF Consulting Ltd|title=Vancouver Homelessness Funding Model: More than just a warm bed|url=http://council.vancouver.ca/20070313/documents/rr1appendix.pdf|publisher=City of Vancouver|accessdate=10 May 2016|format=PDF|date=5 March 2007}}</ref> and according to police, most of them work in the DTES.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=25}} They call the neighbourhood, and contiguous industrial areas near Vancouver's port, the "low track",<ref name="Hutchinson2012">{{cite news|last1=Hutchinson|first1=Brian|title=Years after Pickton's arrest, the killings have stopped in the Downtown Eastside, the violence has not|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/downtown-eastside-vancouver|accessdate=22 April 2016|work= National Post| place=Toronto|date=16 March 2012}}</ref> where they typically earn $5 to $20 for a date.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=26}} Most are [[survival sex worker]]s who use prostitution to support their drug addictions;<ref name="Keller2012">{{cite news|last1=Keller|first1=James|title=Prostitutes' only relief, inquiry hears, is self-medication with drugs|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/prostitutes-only-relief-inquiry-hears-is-self-medication-with-drugs/article558175/|accessdate=4 April 2016|work=Maclean's| place=Toronto|date=6 September 2012}}</ref> up to two thirds say they have been physically or sexually assaulted while working.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=26}} Sex workers, particularly women with children, find it difficult to find housing that they can afford, and often have difficulty leaving prostitution because of criminal records or addictions that make it harder to find jobs.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=26}}
Although [[Aboriginal Canadian|Aboriginals]] make up only 2% of Vancouver's population, approximately 40% of Vancouver's street sex workers are Aboriginal.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=43}} In one 2005 study, 52% of the prostitutes surveyed in Vancouver were Aboriginal, 96% reported having been sexually abused in childhood, and 81% reported childhood physical abuse. Some researchers and Aboriginal advocacy groups have attributed the over-representation of Aboriginals in Vancouver's sex trade to [[transgenerational trauma]], linking it to Canada's colonial history, and in particular to the cultural and individual damaged caused by the [[Canadian Indian residential school system|residential schools]], which previous generations of indigenous Canadians were forced to attend.<ref name="Alarcon2013">{{cite news|last1=Alarcon|first1=Krystal|title=Angel's Story: Trapped in a Violent World|url=https://thetyee.ca/News/2013/03/04/Aboriginal-Sex-Workers-BC/|accessdate=6 April 2016|work=The Tyee|place=Vancouver|date=4 Mar 2013}}</ref>
===Crime and public disorder=== [[File:Peoples Pigeon Park Cropped.jpg|thumb|left|250px|alt=Photograph of people, graffiti-covered walls, and litter in Pigeon Park|Pigeon Park, near Hastings and Carrall Streets]] Reported crime rates in the DTES are higher than in the rest of the city, due mostly to assaults, robberies and public intoxication.<ref name="Rossi2014">{{cite news|last1=Rossi|first1=Cheryl|title=Downtown Eastside: The neighbourhood at a glance|url=http://www.vancourier.com/news/downtown-eastside-the-neighbourhood-at-a-glance-1.871240|accessdate=4 April 2016|work=Vancouver Courier|date=28 February 2014}}</ref> Although the DTES is home to 3% of Vancouver's population, it was the location of 16% of the city's reported sexual assaults in 2012.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=43}} In 2008, it was the location of 34.5% of all reported serious assaults and 22.6% of all robberies in the city.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=22}}
These figures may be an underestimate, as marginalized populations such as DTES residents tend to be less likely to report crime.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=43}} The figures do not indicate how many of the reported crimes were committed by DTES residents; some residents and business owners believe that visitors from other neighbourhoods are responsible for a significant proportion of serious crimes.<ref name="Lupick2016-2"/> According to police, DTES women say that what they fear most are "predatory drug dealers who conduct their business with violence, torture and terror."<ref name="CTV2011">{{cite news|title=Police bust drug ring that used torture, terror|url=http://bc.ctvnews.ca/police-bust-drug-ring-that-used-torture-terror-1.600969|accessdate=6 June 2016|work=CTV News|place=Toronto |agency=The Canadian Press|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
In addition to reported crime, the DTES has highly visible street disorder, which ''[[The New York Times]]'' described as "a shock even to someone familiar with the Lower East Side of Manhattan in the 1980s or the Tenderloin in San Francisco."<ref name="McNeil2011"/> Some government social workers have refused to enter certain SROs out of concern for their own safety, despite being mandated to monitor children who live there.<ref name="Turpel-Lafond2015">{{cite web|last1=Turpel-Lafond|first1=Mary Ellen|title=Paige's Story Abuse, IndIfference and a Young LIfe DIscarded|url=https://www.rcybc.ca/sites/default/files/documents/pdf/reports_publications/rcy-pg-report-final.pdf|publisher=B.C. Representative for Children and Youth|accessdate=24 April 2016|date=May 2015}}</ref> Tourists are often encouraged to avoid the DTES,{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=24}} although they are seldom victims of crime.<ref name="LP">{{cite web|title=Safety in Vancouver|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/canada/vancouver/safety|publisher=Lonely Planet|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> High crime rates and difficulties in obtaining affordable property insurance deter legitimate businesses from opening or staying in the area, resulting in many vacant storefronts.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|pp=22-24}}<ref name=SBIA2012/>
===Poverty=== [[File:Hotel Empress.jpg|thumb|right|250px|alt=refer to caption|The Hotel Empress at 235 East Hastings was built in 1912–1913. Like many SROs in the DTES, it was originally designed for tourists and business travellers, and was converted to residential use in the 20th century.<ref name="Empress1994">{{cite news|title=Hotel Empress|url=http://www.historicplaces.ca/en/rep-reg/place-lieu.aspx?id=8465|accessdate=31 May 2016|work=Canada's Historic Places}}</ref>]] The greater DTES area is significantly poorer than the rest of Vancouver, with a median income of $13,691 versus $47,229 for the city as a whole.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=12}} 53% of the greater DTES population is [[Poverty in Canada|low-income]], compared to 13.6% of the population of [[Metro Vancouver]].{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=11}} In the V6A postal area, whose boundaries are similar to the greater DTES area, 6,339 residents received some form of [[social assistance]] in 2013.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=13}} Of these, 3,193 were considered disabled and 1,461 were considered "employable". The base welfare rate for single adults who are considered employable is $610 per month: $375 per month for shelter and $235 per month for all other expenses.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=13}} Advocates for low-income DTES residents say this amount, which has not increased since 2007, is not enough to live on.<ref name="Lupick2016">{{cite news|last1=Lupick|first1=Travis|title=Downtown Eastside activists fear 2016 will see a spike in Vancouver homeles|url=https://www.straight.com/news/607881/downtown-eastside-activists-fear-2016-will-see-spike-vancouver-homeless|accessdate=24 May 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=6 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=Christopher2012/> In 1981, the base welfare rate was equivalent to $970 per month after [[Inflation adjustment|adjustment for inflation]].<ref name="Christopher2012">{{cite news|last1=Christopher|first1=Ben|title=A Tyee Series Jean Swanson's Advocacy for Vancouver's Impoverished|url=https://thetyee.ca/News/2012/09/10/Jean-Swanson/|accessdate=24 May 2016|work=The Tyee|place=Vancouver|date=10 September 2012}}</ref>
Some DTES residents supplement their incomes through the [[informal sector|informal economy]], through volunteer work which can yield stipends,{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=13}} or through criminal activity or sex work.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=21-26}} A 2008 survey of SRO residents found that the average tenant income from all sources, including the informal economy, was $1,109 per month.<ref name=Lewis2008/>
In addition to issues with addiction and mental illness, DTES residents often have difficulty finding employment due to mental and physical disabilities and lack of education and skills.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|pp=18}} According to a 2009 survey of the 30 blocks in and around the DTES, 62% of the residents over the age of 15 were not considered participants in the labour force, compared to 33% in Vancouver as a whole.<ref name = "Globe and Mail"/>
The DTES is often referred to as "Canada's poorest postal code", although this is not the case.<ref name="Skelton2010">{{cite news|last1=Skelton|first1=Chad|title=Is Vancouver's Downtown Eastside really "Canada's poorest postal code"?|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/staff-blogs/is-vancouvers-downtown-eastside-really-canadas-poorest-postal-code|accessdate=21 August 2016|work=[[Vancouver Sun]]|date=10 February 2010}}</ref>
===Housing=== {{See also|Homelessness in Vancouver}} Both homelessness and substandard housing are major issues in the DTES, that confound the neighbourhood's problems with addiction and mental illness. In 2012, there were 846 homeless people in the greater DTES area, including 171 who were not in some form of shelter.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|p=24}} The DTES homeless made up approximately half of the city's total homeless population,<ref name="Lupick2016"/> over a third of whom are Aboriginal.<ref name="Thompson2016">{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Matt|title=Vancouver Homeless Count 2016|url=http://vancouver.ca/files/cov/homeless-count-2016-report.pdf|publisher=City of Vancouver|accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
Thousands of DTES residents live in SROs, which provide low-cost rooms without private kitchens or bathrooms,<ref name="Lupick2013">{{cite news|last1=Lupick|first1=Travis|title=Study finds steep drug and mental health challenges for Downtown Eastside single-occupancy tenants|url=https://www.straight.com/news/408591/study-finds-steep-drug-and-mental-health-challenges-downtown-eastside-single-occupancy-tenants|accessdate=5 April 2016|work= Georgia Straight|place=Vancouver|date=10 August 2013}}</ref> Although conditions in SROs vary considerably, they have become notorious for their squalor and chaos. Many are more than 100 years old and in extreme disrepair, with shortages of basic necessities such as heat and functioning plumbing. In 2007, it was reported that four out of five rooms had bed bugs, cockroaches, and fire code violations.<ref name=Paulsen2007/> Even at their best, the SROS have a lack of living space that results in tenants spending more time in the public spaces of the DTES, including its street-based drug scene.<ref name=UHRI2013/>
SRO landlords have often been called "slumlords" for failing to fix problems, and illegally evicting tenants.<ref name="Colebourn2016">{{cite news|last1=Colebourn|first1=John|title='They thought I was going to back down and leave': DTES tenant's court case shines light on practices of Sahota landlords|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/they-thought-i-was-going-to-back-down-and-leave-dtes-tenants-court-case-shines-light-on-practices-of-sahota-landlords|accessdate=16 August 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=10 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="Cole2011">{{cite news|last1=Cole|first1=Yolande|title=Lawsuit launched against Downtown Eastside building owners|url=https://www.straight.com/article-401814/vancouver/lawsuit-launched-against-downtown-eastside-building-owners|accessdate=16 August 2016|work=Georgia Straight| place=Vancouver|date=29 June 2011}}</ref> The city has often been slow to force SRO owners to make major repairs, saying that owners could not afford to make them without raising rents.<ref name="CBC2016">{{cite news|title=Kerry Jang on city's broken-down SROs: 'There's only so much we can do'|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/kerry-jang-sro-landlords-city-policy-1.3391067|accessdate=8 April 2016|work=CBC News|place=Toronto |date=5 January 2016}}</ref>
===Health and well-being=== [[File:Tent Sale at Army Navy Store.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A young person sleeping in a doorway in a DTES alley|Around half of the city's homeless people live in the greater DTES area. Street homelessness was relatively rare in Vancouver until the 1990s.]] A 2013 study of SRO residents in the greater DTES area found that 18.4% were [[HIV positive]] and 70.3% were positive for [[hepatitis C]].<ref name="Vila-Rodriguez2013"/> Few of those infected with hepatitis C receive treatment.<ref name="Vila-Rodriguez2013"/><ref name=Mercier2015/> The DTES population also has higher rates of [[tuberculosis]] and [[syphilis]] than the rest of the province,{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=17}} and injection drug users are susceptible to other infections such as [[endocarditis]].<ref name = Wood2003/> Aboriginals are at the greatest risk from disease.<ref name= Adilman2000/>
Amongst the most vulnerable DTES residents, common issues with psychosocial [[well-being]] include low self-worth, lack of personal safety, lack of respect from others, [[social isolation]], and low education levels.<ref name=Adilman2000>Steve Adilman, MD, Gordon Kliewer, RN. [http://www.bcmj.org/articles/pain-and-wasting-main-and-hastings-perspective-vancouver-native-health-society-medical-clin "Pain and wasting on Main and Hastings: A perspective from the Vancouver Native Health Society Medical Clinic"]. ''BCMJ'', Vol. 42, No. 9, November 2000, page(s) 422-425</ref><ref>Campbell 2009, chapter 4</ref> Many have lost custody of their children.{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=24}} A 2000 report from the Vancouver Native Health Society Medical Clinic said, "Many individuals are survivors of severe childhood trauma. Negative experiences such as family violence, parental substance abuse, sexual and emotional abuse, suicide, divorce, and [[Aboriginal residential schools|residential school]] atrocities are the norm."<ref name=Adilman2000/> Many DTES residents are too unstable to keep appointments or reliably take medication.<ref>Campbell 2009, Chapter 4</ref>
Life expectancy in the greater DTES area is 79.9 years, a significant improvement since the mid-1990s.<ref name="MacQueen2012">{{cite news|last1=MacQueen|first1=Ken|title=Vancouver's Downtown Eastside gets new lease on life|url=http://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/getting-a-new-lease-on-life/|accessdate=11 May 2016|work=Maclean's| place=Toronto|date=15 October 2012}}</ref> Some of the increase may, however, be explained by the migration of healthier residents to the neighbourhoods surrounding the DTES.<ref name=MacQueen2012/> A 2015 study of DTES SRO residents found that they were eight times more likely to die than the national average, mostly due to [[psychosis]] and hepatitis C-related liver dysfunction.<ref name="Mercier2015">{{cite news|last1=Mercier|first1=Stephanie|title=Vancouver's Downtown Eastside residents dying at 8 times the national average|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/vancouver-s-downtown-eastside-residents-dying-at-8-times-the-national-average-1.3223569|accessdate=2 May 2016|issue=10 September 2015|work=CBC News|place=Toronto}}</ref>
==Culture== [[File:Heart of the Community mural.jpeg|thumb|right|alt=Mosaic sidewalk art on East Hastings Street, depicting a heart and the Community "The Heart of the City"|Mosaic sidewalk art on East Hastings Street]] Although many outsiders fear the DTES,{{sfn|Cran|2008|p=31}} its residents take pride in their neighbourhood and describe it as having multiple positive assets.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2014|p=17}} DTES residents say the area has a strong [[sense of community]] and cultural heritage.<ref name=BCS2010/> They describe their neighbours as being accepting and having empathy for people with addictions and health issues.<ref name=BCS2010/> According to the City, [[Hastings Street (Vancouver)|Hastings Street]] is valued by SRO residents as "a place to meet friends, get support, access services and feel like they belong."{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2014|p=50}}
The area has had a robust tradition of advocacy for its marginalized residents since at least the 1970s, when the [[Downtown Eastside Residents Association]] (DERA) was formed.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 2">Campbell 2009, chapter 2</ref> Over the years, the DTES community has consistently resisted many attempts to "clean up" the neighbourhood by dispersing its close-knit residents.{{sfn|Cran|2008|p=11}} Successful resident-led initiatives to improve conditions in the DTES include the transformation of the then-closed Carnegie Library into a community centre in 1980,<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 2"/> the opening of an unlicensed supervised injection site in 2003, which led to the founding of [[Insite]];{{sfn|Cran|2008|p=27}} improvements to [[Oppenheimer Park]],{{sfn|Cran|2008|p=10}} and the creation of CRAB Park.
In 2010, the V6A postal area, which includes most of the DTES, had the second-highest concentration of artists in the city.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|pp=47-48}} Artists made up 4.4% of the labour force, compared to 2.3% in the city as a whole.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2013|pp=47-48}} The greater DTES area is the location of several art galleries, artist-run centres and studios.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2014|pp=143-147}} Notable annual events include the ''Downtown Eastside Heart of the City Festival'', which showcases the art, culture, and history of the neighbourhood, and the ''Powell Street Festival'' in [[Oppenheimer Park]], which celebrates Japanese-Canadian arts and culture. [[City Opera of Vancouver]], the [[Dancing on the Edge Festival]], and other artists regularly perform in DTES venues such as the Carnegie Centre, the [[Firehall Arts Centre]], and the Goldcorp Centre for the Arts at the Woodward's site. In 2010, [[Sam Sullivan]], former mayor of Vancouver, said that in the DTES, "Behind the visible people who clearly have a lot of troubles, there's a community. Some very intelligent people say this is the cultural heart of the city."<ref name="NYT2010">{{cite news|last1=Bishop|first1=Greg|title=In the Shadow of the Olympics|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/05/sports/olympics/05eastside.html|accessdate=2 April 2016|work=The New York Times|date=4 February 2010}}</ref>
==Law enforcement== {{Reduced pull quote |right | For the police, success is measured in how well the drugs are kept corralled on Hastings between Cambie and Main, where they can expect the fewest complaints. Arrests are infrequent, and when they occur they are counterproductive... Like a hydra, direct enforcement paradoxically crowds the streets with the incarcerated dealers multiplying replacements.| Reid Shier, former DTES art gallery director/curator |<ref name="Douglas 2002, Introduction">Douglas 2002, Introduction</ref>}} [[File:Vancouver Police Speak to Street Girl.jpg|thumb|right|280px|alt=Two VPD officers in short sleeves stand talking to a woman sitting on the sidewalk, wearing a heavy coat|Despite relatively progressive policies, trust of police in the DTES remains low.]] In comparison to other Canadian cities, the [[Vancouver Police Department|VPD]] is generally [[Progressivism|progressive]] in dealing with drugs and sex work, emphasizing harm reduction over law enforcement.<ref name=Li2014/> Since the 1980s, the VPD has generally ignored drug use in the DTES, as the sheer volume of users makes it unfeasible to arrest all of them.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 13"/> A large-scale police crackdown on DTES drug users in 2003 made no difference except to displace drug use to adjacent neighbourhoods.<ref>Wood E, Spittal PM, Small W, et al. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC400719/#r10-28 "Displacement of Canada's largest public illicit drug market in response to a police crackdown"]. ''CMAJ : Canadian Medical Association Journal''. 2004;170(10):1551-1556. doi:10.1503/cmaj.1031928.</ref> To encourage people to call for help when a drug user is overdosing, paramedics rather than police respond to 911 calls about overdose deaths, except in cases where public safety is at risk.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 13"/>
Nationwide efforts to reduce the supply of drugs through law enforcement have had minimal impact on the easy availability or low prices of illicit drugs in Vancouver.<ref name="UHRI2013"/> By former mayor [[Mike Harcourt]]'s estimate, police intercept only 2% of the drugs that enter the city.<ref name="Cameron">{{cite book|last1=Ken Cameron, Mike Harcourt|title=City Making in Paradise: Nine Decisions that Saved Vancouver|date=2009|publisher=D & M Publishers|page=198}}</ref> Vancouver police guidelines on dealing with sex workers emphasize focusing on addressing violence, [[human trafficking]], and involvement of youth or gangs in prostitution, whereas sex involving consenting adults is not an enforcement priority.<ref name="Li2014">{{cite news|last1=Li|first1=Wanyee|title=Vancouver police to prioritize safety over anti-prostitution laws|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/vancouver-police-to-prioritize-safety-over-anti-prostitution-laws/article21980647/|accessdate=12 May 2016|work= Globe and Mail|place=Toronto|date=5 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="Rossi2012">{{cite news|last1=Rossi|first1=Cheryl|title=Advocates laud new Vancouver police 'sex work' guidelines|url=http://www.vancourier.com/news/advocates-laud-new-vancouver-police-sex-work-guidelines-1.377575|accessdate=12 May 2016|work=Vancouver Courier|date=22 March 2012}}</ref>
Relations between police and DTES women were strained by police shortcomings that allowed serial killer [[Robert Pickton]] to prey on the community for years before he was arrested in 2002; the VPD apologized in 2010 for its failures in apprehending him.<ref name="Stueck2016">{{cite news|last1=Stueck|first1=Wendy|title=SisterWatch initiative has not built trust between police, DTES: report|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/sisterwatch-initiative-has-not-built-trust-between-police-and-dtes-report/article29757030/|accessdate=18 May 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=25 April 2016}}</ref> In 2003, the [[Pivot Legal Society]] filed 50 complaints from DTES residents alleging [[police misconduct]].<ref name="Theodore2009">{{cite news|last1=Theodore|first1=Terri|title=Allow police misconduct hearings, legal group urges judge|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/allow-police-misconduct-hearings-legal-group-urges-judge/article4122209/|accessdate=7 June 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|agency=Canadian Press|date=17 March 2009}}</ref> An investigation by the [[RCMP]], in which several VPD officers and the police chief failed to co-operate, found that 14 of those allegations were substantiated.<ref name="Theodore2009"/> In 2007, Pivot agreed to withdraw its remaining complaints, following apologies and changes to VPD policies and procedures.<!-- explain what changes were made --><ref name="Province2007">{{cite news|title=Activists reach pact with police over Downtown Eastside issues; New procedures erase list of complaints |work=The Province|place=Vancouver|date=6 November 2007 | page=A7}}</ref>
In 2008, the VPD implemented a crackdown on minor offences, such as illegal vending on sidewalks and jaywalking. The ticketing blitz was stopped after objections from community groups, so that residents with unpaid tickets – particularly women and sex workers – would be less afraid to approach police to report serious safety concerns.<ref name="Howell2014">{{cite news|last1=Howell|first1=Mike|title=Vancouver Police Department sidesteps stance on DTES jaywalkers|url=http://www.vancourier.com/news/vancouver-police-department-sidesteps-stance-on-dtes-jaywalkers-1.796617|accessdate=12 May 2016|work=Vancouver Courier|date=21 January 2014}}</ref>
In 2010, police launched an initiative to combat violence against DTES women, that resulted in the convictions of several violent offenders.<ref name="SisterWatch">{{cite web|title=Project Sister Watch|url=http://vancouver.ca/police/organization/investigation/investigative-services/major-crime/sister-watch.html|publisher=Vancouver Police Department|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> However, the level of trust toward police remains low.<ref name=Stueck2016/> According to some DTES activists, "gentrification/condos and police brutality", rather than drugs, are the two worst problems in the neighbourhood.<ref name="Swanson2009">{{cite news|last1=Swanson|first1=Jean|title=Residents suggest solutions to Downtown Eastside problems|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/community-blogs/residents-suggest-solutions-to-downtown-eastside-problems|accessdate=31 May 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=24 October 2009}}</ref>
==Housing availability and affordability== {{Reduced pull quote|right |Any discussion of improving the continuum of care for addiction must include housing as a basic component, particularly for the most vulnerable individuals coping with homelessness, addiction, and mental illness.| B.C. Medical Association|<ref name = BCMA2009/>}} The City refers to the housing and homelessness situation in the DTES as a "crisis".{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2014|p=28}} There is wide support amongst governments, experts, and community groups on a [[Housing First]] model, which prioritizes stable, quality housing as a precursor to other interventions for the homeless, those who use drugs, or those with mental illness.<ref name = BCMA2009/> Many people with severe addiction and/or mental illness require [[supportive housing]].<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 17"/>
As the DTES has many low-income adults who live alone and are at risk of homelessness, trends in housing options for low-income adults are of central importance to the neighbourhood. Although SROs have well-known problems, each SRO resident who loses their room and ends up on the street is estimated to cost the provincial government approximately $30,000 to $40,000 per year in additional services.<ref name="PBC2013">{{cite web|title=Project Report: SRO Renewal Initiative|url=http://www.partnershipsbc.ca/files-4/documents/PBC_SRO.pdf|publisher=Partnerships British Columbia|accessdate=11 May 2016|date=June 2013}}</ref> [[File:6th ANNUAL WOMEN’S HOUSING MARCH (7998506820).jpg|thumb|left|alt=Photograph of a protestor holding a sign saying, "HOMES NOT CAPITALISM"|A protestor's sign during a march for housing]] In recent years, the number of units designed for low-income singles has increased slightly: In the downtown area (Burrard Street to Clark Drive) there were 11,371 units in 1993 and 12,126 units in 2013.<ref name=Housing2014/> The number of privately owned SROs declined during this time by 3283 units, while the number of social housing units increased by 4038 units.<ref name=Housing2014>{{cite web|title=Housing & Homelessness Strategy Targets 2012-2014 2012 Report Card|url=http://council.vancouver.ca/20130212/documents/rr2presentation.pdf|publisher=City of Vancouver|accessdate=3 May 2016|date=12 February 2013}}</ref> In 2014, an additional 300 privately owned SRO units were lost.<ref name=SRO2015/>
However, rents in many of those units have risen. Rents in social housing units for low-income singles are fixed at the shelter component of welfare rates, but rents in privately owned SROs can vary. In 2013, 24% of privately owned SROs rented at the base welfare shelter rate of $375 per month, down from 60% in 2007.<ref name="SRO2015">{{cite web|title=2015 Report on Homelessness and Related Actions on SROs|url=http://council.vancouver.ca/20150707/documents/rr2presentation.pdf|publisher=City of Vancouver|accessdate=3 May 2016|format=PDF|date=15 July 2015}}</ref> According to one advocacy group, the average lowest rent in privately owned hotels in the greater DTES area was $517 per month in 2015, and there were no vacant rooms renting at less than $425 per month.<ref name="CCAP2016">{{cite news|author1=Jean Swanson |author2=King-mong Chan |author3=Maria Wallstam |title=Our Homes Can't Wait: CCAP's 2015 Hotel Survey and Housing Report|url=https://ccapvancouver.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/2015hotelreport.pdf|accessdate=8 May 2016|publisher=Carnegie Community Action Project|date=2016}}</ref>
The city has implemented a bylaw to discourage the redevelopment of SROs.<ref name="Lee2015">{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Jeff|title=Vancouver introduces harsh SRO rules to dissuade owners from 'renovicting'|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/business/Vancouver+introduces+harsh+rules+dissuade+owners+from+renovicting/11234522/story.html|accessdate=7 April 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=21 July 2015}}</ref> Advocates for SRO tenants argue that the city's bylaw does not go far enough, as it does not prevent rent increases.<ref name="Lee2015"/> The city says that only the province, not the city, has the [[jurisdiction]] to control rents, and that the province should raise welfare rates.<ref name="Murphy2014">{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Meghan|title=Renovictions on Vancouver's Downtown Eastside Aren’t Stopping Anytime Soon|url=https://www.vice.com/en_ca/read/renovictions-on-vancouvers-downtown-eastside-show-arent-stopping-anytime-soon|accessdate=24 May 2016|work=Vice|date=24 April 2014}}</ref>
Since 2007, the provincial government has acquired 23 privately owned SRO hotels in the greater DTES area, containing 1,500 units. It undertook extensive renovations in 13 of those buildings at a cost of $143.3 million, of which $29.1 million was paid by the federal government.<ref name="Morton2015">{{cite news|last1=Morton|first1=Brian|title=Downtown Eastside tenants love their renovated SRO suite|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/life/Downtown+Eastside+tenants+love+their+renovated+suite/10853080/story.html|accessdate=11 May 2016|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=28 February 2015}}</ref> Due to rising rents and often-decrepit conditions in the area's remaining 4,484 privately owned SROs, DTES activists have called for governments to replace them with a further 5,000 social housing units for low-income singles.<ref name="Kane2013">{{cite news|last1=Kane|first1=Laura|title=Vancouver's vision for Downtown Eastside stokes anti-gentrification protests|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2013/05/25/vancouvers_vision_for_downtown_eastside_stokes_antigentrification_protests.html|accessdate=3 May 2016|work=Toronto Star|date=26 May 2013}}</ref>
==Migration patterns== The DTES has a history of attracting migrants with mental health and addiction issues from across B.C. and Canada, with many drawn by its drug market, affordable housing, and services.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|pp=28-29}}<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 16"/><ref name="VCH2015"/><ref name=Mate2016/> Between 1991 and 2007, the DTES population increased by 140%.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 16"/>
A 2016 study found that 52% of those DTES residents who experience chronic homelessness and serious mental-health issues, had migrated from outside Vancouver in the previous 10 years. This proportion of the population has tripled in the last decade.<ref name="Woo2016-2">{{cite news|last1=Woo|first1=Andrea|title=Half of Downtown Eastside's homeless residents came from other areas: study|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/half-of-downtown-eastside-homeless-residents-are-from-out-of-town-study/article28069065/|accessdate=5 April 2016|work=CBC News|place=Toronto |date=7 January 2016}}</ref> The same study found that once migrants had settled in the DTES, their conditions worsened.<ref name="Woo2016-2"/> A 2013 study of tenants of DTES SROs found that while 93% of those surveyed were born in Canada, only 13% were born in Vancouver.<ref name = Lupick2013/> Vancouver Coastal Health estimates that half of the population that uses its health services in the DTES are long-term residents, and that there is a population turnover of 15 to 20% each year.<ref name="Woo2016-2"/>
==Concentration of services controversy== {{Reduced pull quote|right|You just keep dumping money in, building social housing and filling it up with people from all around the region and the country ... they all get chemically dependent, and it's just more sales for the drug dealers.|[[Philip Owen]], former Vancouver mayor|<ref name=Hopper2014/>}}
{{Reduced pull quote |right|The Downtown Eastside, really, has become the last place where everybody runs to from across Canada. It's the last, best place for people who are the most marginalized people in the country.|Karen Ward, DTES resident|<ref name="Lupick2014">{{cite news|last1=Lupick|first1=Travis|title=Downtown Eastside residents fear dispersal due to Local Area Plan|url=https://www.straight.com/news/622151/downtown-eastside-residents-fear-dispersal-due-local-area-plan|accessdate=18 April 2016|work= Georgia Straight| place=Vancouver|date=9 April 2014}}</ref>}}
{{Reduced pull quote|right|It's the NIMBYism of the other 23 communities in the city that is the Downtown Eastside's greatest problem. And what the city needs to do is work to put significantly more services in different communities.|Scott Clark, Aboriginal Life in Vancouver Enhancement Society|<ref name=McMartin2014/>}} The DTES is the site of many service offerings including social housing, health care, free meals and clothing, [[harm reduction]] for drug users, housing assistance, employment preparation, adult education, children's programs, emergency housing, arts and recreation, and legal advocacy.<ref name="Culbert2014"/> In 2014, the ''[[Vancouver Sun]]'' reported that there were 260 social services and housing sites in the greater DTES area, spending $360 million per year.<ref name="Culbert2014"/> No other Canadian city has concentrated services to this degree in one small area.<ref name="Culbert2014">{{cite news|author1=Culbert, Lori |author2=Peter McMartin,|title=Downtown Eastside: 260 agencies, housing sites crowd Downtown Eastside|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/health/Downtown+Eastside+agencies+housing+sites+crowd+Downtown+Eastside+with+video/9983274/story.html|accessdate=6 April 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=27 June 2014}}</ref>
Proponents of the high level of services say that it is necessary to meet the complex needs of the DTES population.<ref name=Culbert2014/> For some residents, the sense of community and acceptance that they find in the DTES makes it a unique place of healing for them.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 17"/>
The practice of locating a large number of services in the DTES has also been criticized for attracting vulnerable people to an area where drugs, crime, and disorder are entrenched. Some advocates for vulnerable populations believe that many DTES residents would have a better quality of life and improved chances of health if they could separate from the neighbourhood's predatory drug pushers and pimps.<ref name=Hopper2014/><ref name="Turpel-Lafond2015"/><ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 17">Campbell 2009, chapter 17</ref><ref name="Benoit2001">{{cite web|author1=Benoit, Ceclia |author2=Dena Carroll|title=Marginalized Voices From The Downtown Eastside: Aboriginal Women Speak About Their Health Experiences|url=http://sheway.vcn.bc.ca/files/2012/07/Marginalized-voices-from-the-downtown-eastside-Aboriginal-women-speak-about-their-healt-experiences.pdf|publisher=The National Network on Environments and Women's Health, York University|accessdate=3 May 2016|format=PDF|date=1 March 2001}}</ref>
During the City's 2014 planning process for the greater DTES, two-thirds of those who participated said they wanted to stay in the area.<ref name=Culbert2014/> But a 2008 survey of SRO tenants had indicated that 70% wanted to leave the DTES.<ref name=Lewis2008/> The City's 30-year plan is for two-thirds of the city's future social housing to be located in the greater DTES area.<ref name=Culbert2014/>
=== Views on services in other neighbourhoods ===
Vancouver Coastal Health says that the lack of appropriate care for complex social and health issues outside of the DTES often does not allow people "the choice to remain in their home community where their natural support systems exist... A common barrier that prevents mentally ill and addicted people from living outside of the DTES is a lack of appropriate services and supports, and too often clients who do secure housing outside the neighbourhood return to the DTES regularly because of the lack of supports found in other communities."<ref name="VCH2015">{{cite web|title=Downtown Eastside Second Generation Health System Strategy|url=https://www.vch.ca/media/VCH-Downtown-Eastside-DTES-Second-Generation-Strategy-2017_2.pdf|publisher=[[Vancouver Coastal Health]]|accessdate=8 April 2016|date=24 February 2015}}</ref>
Proposals to add social housing and services for those with addiction and/or mental health issues to other Metro Vancouver neighborhoods are often met with [[Nimbyism]], even when residents selected for such projects would be low-risk individuals.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ludvigsen | first1 = Mykle | title = Not in My Backyard: Nimby alive and well in Vancouver | journal = Visions | volume = 2 | issue = 6 | pages = 15–16 | publisher = BC Partners for Mental Health and Addictions Information | location = Vancouver | date = Summer 2005 | url = http://www.heretohelp.bc.ca/sites/default/files/visions_stigma_discrim.pdf}}</ref> A 2012 poll of [[Metro Vancouver]] residents found that although nine out of 10 of those surveyed wanted the homeless to have access to services they need, 54% believed that "housing in their community should be there for the people who can afford it."<ref name="Woo2012">{{cite news|last1=Woo|first1=Andrea|title=NIMBYism based on ‘fear of the unknown’|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=4 October 2012}}</ref> Some commentators have suggested that Vancouver residents tacitly agree to have the DTES act as a de facto [[ghetto]] for the most troubled individuals in the city.<ref name="McMartin2014">{{cite news|last1=McMartin|first1=Pete|title=Pete McMartin: Vancouver's Downtown Eastside is a ghetto made by outsider|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/life/Pete+McMartin+Vancouver+Downtown+Eastside+ghetto+made+outsiders+with+video/9983272/story.html|accessdate=21 April 2016|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=27 June 2014}}</ref>
==Gentrification controversy== {{Reduced pull quote|right|This community could be wiped off the face of the map. In the last three or four years the character of the neighbourhood has totally changed. Basically affordable rentals are a thing of the past.| Harold Lavender, DTES resident |<ref name="Colebourn2016-2">{{cite news|last1=Colebourn|first1=John|title=Low-income rental units drying up in Vancouver's Downtown Eastside|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/life/income+rental+units+drying+vancouver+downtown+eastside/11799989/story.html|accessdate=9 May 2016|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=20 March 2016}}</ref>}} {{Reduced pull quote|right|Years of experience in other urban centres make it clear that maintaining the DTES as a high or special needs social housing enclave, over the long term will not help to stabilize either the community or the city as a whole.|Strathcona Business Improvement Association, Ray-Cam Community Association, and Inner City Safety Society|<ref name="SBIA2012">{{cite web|last1=Strathcona Business Improvement Association, Ray-Cam Community Association, and Inner City Safety Society|title=Vancouver's Downtown Eastside: A Community in Need of Balance|url=http://strathconabia.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/DTES-A-Community-in-Need-of-Balance.pdf|accessdate=6 April 2016|date=2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528193327/http://strathconabia.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/DTES-A-Community-in-Need-of-Balance.pdf|archivedate=28 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>}} {{See also|Gentrification of Vancouver}} The DTES lies a few blocks east of the most expensive commercial real estate in the city.<ref name="Douglas 2002, Introduction"/> Since the mid-2000s, new development in the DTES has brought a mixture of market-rate housing (primarily [[condominium]]s), [[social housing]], office spaces, restaurants, and shops.<ref name="AP2012">{{cite news|title=Vancouver's Downtown Eastside feeling gentrification squeeze|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/vancouver-s-downtown-eastside-feeling-gentrification-squeeze-1.1190127|accessdate=7 April 2016|work=CBC News|place=Toronto |agency=The Canadian Press|date=26 December 2012}}</ref> Property values in the DTES area increased by 303% between 2001 and 2013.<ref name="SIA2014">{{cite web|title=Downtown Eastside Social Impact Assessment - Draft Report|url=http://vancouver.ca/files/cov/social-impact-assessment-2014-feb-26.pdf|publisher=City of Vancouver|accessdate=8 April 2016|date=15 February 2014}}</ref> Prices at the newer retail establishments are often far higher than low-income residents can afford.<ref name=AP2012/>
The city promotes [[mixed-income housing]], and requires new large housing developments in the DTES to set aside 20% of their units for social housing.<ref name=AP2012/> As of 2014, in a section of Hastings Street from Carrall Street to Heatley Avenue, at least 60% of units must be dedicated to social housing and the rest must be rental units.<ref name="Robinson2014">{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Matthew|title=Vancouver's $1-billion Downtown Eastside plan approved by council|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Vancouver+billion+Downtown+Eastside+plan+approved+council/9624358/story.html|accessdate=18 April 2016|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=15 March 2014}}</ref> Rents in at least one-third of new social housing units are not permitted to exceed the shelter component of welfare rates.<ref name="Robinson2014"/>
Proponents say that new developments revitalize the area, improve the quality of life, provide new social housing, and encourage a stronger retail environment and a stabilizing street presence.<ref name="BCS2010">{{cite web|title=Vancouver Downtown Eastside Putting it All Together: Plans Policies, Programs, Projects, and Proposals: A Synthesis|url=http://buildingcommunitysociety.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/07/20100723_BCS_Synthesis_FIN.pdf|publisher=Building Community Society of Greater Vancouver|accessdate=5 April 2016|date=July 2010}}</ref><ref name=AP2012/> They emphasize that their goal is for the DTES to include a mixture of income levels and avoid the problems associated with [[concentrated poverty]], not to become an expensive [[yuppie]]-oriented neighbourhood like nearby [[Yaletown]].<ref name=BCS2010/><ref name="Mickleburgh2013">{{cite news|last1=Mickleburgh|first1=Rod|title=Mike Harcourt weighs in on delicate issues behind Pidgin protests|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/mike-harcourt-weighs-in-on-delicate-issues-behind-pidgin-protests/article9808773/|accessdate=24 May 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=14 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="Mason2008">{{cite news|last1=Mason|first1=Gary|title=Finally, an issue that sets mayoral candidates apart|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/finally-an-issue-that-sets-mayoral-candidates-apart/article716481/|accessdate=18 May 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=23 October 2008}}</ref>
Others oppose the addition of market housing and upscale businesses to the DTES, in the belief that these changes will drive up prices, displace low-income residents, and make poor people feel less at home.<ref name="BCS2010"/><ref name="Mackie2014">{{cite news|last1=Mackie|first1=John|title=The Battle of Hastings: Notorious Vancouver street in for big changes — and conflicts|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/Battle+Hastings+Notorious+Vancouver+street+changes+conflicts/9593502/story.html|accessdate=6 April 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=6 March 2014}}</ref> Protests against new businesses and housing developments have occasionally turned violent.<ref name=Kane2013/>
==Costs== [[File:Potters_Place_Mission.jpg|thumb|right|alt=refer to caption|250px|The crowded sidewalk of Hastings Street, near Main Street]] Several overlapping sets of data exist on costs related to the DTES:
* '''DTES-specific costs:''' Of the estimated $360 million per year to operate 260 social services and housing sites in the greater DTES area, three quarters of the spending is funded by governments, and the rest by private donors.<ref name="Culbert2014"/> This figure includes [[operating costs]] of a range of organizations including neighbourhood health care services, but does not include standard city operations, the [[capital costs]] of building social housing or other infrastructure, or hospital costs.<ref name="Culbert2014"/> * '''Wider-area costs related to issues that are concentrated in the DTES:''' In the closest hospital to the DTES, [[St. Paul's Hospital (Vancouver)|Saint Paul's]], injection drug use leads to approximately 15% of admissions.<ref name=Wood2003>{{cite journal |last= Wood|first=Evan |last2=Kerr |first2=Thomas | first3= Patricia M. | last3= Spittal | first4= Mark W. | last4= Tyndall | first5= Michael V. | last5= O'shaughnessy | first6= Martin T. | last6= Schechter |title=The health care and fiscal costs of the illicit drug use epidemic: The impact of conventional drug control strategies |url=http://bcmj.org/article/health-care-and-fiscal-costs-illicit-drug-use-epidemic-impact-conventional-drug-control-stra |journal= BC Medical Journal | date=April 2003 |publisher= |volume=45 |issue=3 |pages=128–134 |doi= |access-date=23 August 2016}}</ref> The annual cost of ambulances responding to overdoses in Vancouver is $500,000,<ref name= Wood2003/> and the cost of police response to calls involving mental health problems is estimated to be $9 million per year.{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=2}} * '''Costs per individual:''' For each untreated drug addict, the costs to society, including crime, judicial costs, and health care, are estimated to be at least $45,000 per year.<ref name="Ellis2016">{{cite news|last1=Ellis|first1=Erin|title=Injecting common painkiller an alternative to heroin, Vancouver study finds|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/injecting-common-painkiller-an-alternative-to-heroin-study-finds|accessdate=6 June 2016|work=Vancouver Sun|date=7 April 2016}}</ref> The government-paid lifetime healthcare cost per HIV-infected injection drug user is estimated at $150,000.<ref name= Wood2003/> A 2008 study estimated that each homeless person in B.C. costs $55,000 per year in government-paid costs related to healthcare, corrections, and social services, whereas providing housing and support would cost $37,000 per year.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 16"/> Costs per individual vary widely: A 2016 study found that 107 chronic offenders in the DTES incur public service costs of $247,000 per person per year.<ref name=Woo2016/>
==Housing strategies== [[File:Ovaltine Cafe and Afton Hotel.jpg|thumb|left|alt=refer to caption|The Ovaltine Cafe at 251 E. Hastings has served the neighbourhood since the 1940s.<ref name="Rossi2014-2">{{cite news|last1=Rossi|first1=Cheryl|title=Downtown Eastside: ‘It's just the Ovaltine’|url=http://www.vancourier.com/news/downtown-eastside-it-s-just-the-ovaltine-1.871206|accessdate=31 May 2016|work=Vancouver Courier|date=28 February 2014}}</ref> The upper portion of the building is an SRO hotel.]] Although housing and homelessness are often perceived as being municipal issues, social housing is traditionally funded primarily by senior levels of government, which receive 92% of tax revenue in Canada.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 16"/> [[Libby Davies]], a former DTES activist and Member of Parliament, called for a National Housing Strategy in 2009, saying that Canada is the world's only industrialized country with no national housing plan.<ref name="Campbell 2009, chapter 17"/>
In 2014, the City of Vancouver approved a 30-year plan for the greater DTES area. It sets out a goal of having 4,400 units of social housing added to the greater DTES area, 3,350 units of social housing added elsewhere in the city, and 1,900 units of new supportive housing scattered throughout the city.{{sfn|City of Vancouver|2014|p=97}}<ref name="Dhillon2014">{{cite news|last1=Dhillon|first1=Sunny|title=Vancouver reveals $1-billion plan for Downtown Eastside revival|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/vancouver-reveals-1-billion-plan-for-downtown-eastside-revival/article17155956/?ts=160418134141&ord=1|accessdate=18 April 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=27 February 2014}}</ref> The cost of implementing the plan is estimated at $1 billion, of which $220-million would be paid by the city, $300-million by developers, and more than $500-million from the provincial and/or national governments.<ref name="Dhillon2014"/> The provincial government, which recently invested $300 million in social housing in Vancouver, said that it will not be funding the proposed housing expansion, and that its housing strategy had shifted towards other models such as rent assistance rather than construction.<ref name="Mackie2014-2">{{cite news|last1=Mackie|first1=John|title=City unveils $1-billion plan for Vancouver's Downtown Eastside|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/business/City+unveils+billion+plan+Vancouver+Downtown+Eastside/9561041/story.html|accessdate=18 April 2016|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=26 February 2014}}</ref>
==Addiction and mental illness strategies== In 2001, the city adopted a [[Four Pillars drug strategy]] consisting of four equally important "pillars": [[Substance abuse prevention|prevention]], [[Drug rehabilitation|treatment]], enforcement, and [[harm reduction]]. Advocates of the Four Pillars strategy say that the 36 recommendations associated with the policy have only been partly implemented, with prevention, treatment, and harm reduction all being underfunded.<ref name=Katic2014/> Across Canada, 94% of drug strategy dollars are spent on enforcement.<ref name=Wood2003/> The city's 2014 Local Area Plan for the DTES does not propose solutions to the neighbourhood's drug problems; an article in the ''[[National Post]]'' described it as a "221-page document that expertly skirted around any mention of the Downtown Eastside as a failed community in need of a drastic turnaround."<ref name=Hopper2014/>
The VPD, B.C. Medical Association, and City of Vancouver have asked the province to urgently increase capacity for treating addiction and mental illness.{{sfn|Wilson-Bates|2008|p=22}}<ref name = BCMA2009/> In 2009, the BCMA asked that detoxification be available on demand, with no waiting period, by 2012.<ref name=BCMA2009/> A 2016 study of youth who used illicit drugs in Vancouver indicated that 28% had tried unsuccessfully to access [[addiction treatment]] in the previous 6 months, with the lack of success mostly due to being placed on waiting lists.<ref name=DeBeck2016>{{cite journal | last1= DeBeck | first1=Kora | first2= Thomas | last2=Kerr | first3= Seonaid | last3=Nolan | first4= Huiru | last4=Dong | first5=Julio | last5=Montaner | first6=Evan | last6=Wood|title=Inability to access addiction treatment predicts injection initiation among street-involved youth in a Canadian setting|journal=Substance Abuse Treatment, Prevention, and Policy|date=6 January 2016|volume=11|issue=1|doi=10.1186/s13011-015-0046-x|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s13011-015-0046-x}}</ref>
After the city and police department described an emerging mental health crisis in Vancouver in 2013, the province implemented three of their five recommendations within a year, including new [[Assertive Community Treatment]] teams and a nine-bed urgent care facility at St. Paul's Hospital.<ref name="Woo2014">{{cite news|last1=Woo|first1=Andrea|title=A year after Vancouver declares mental health crisis, cases continue to climb|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/vancouvers-act-teams-need-more-action-to-battle-mental-health-issue/article21154660/|accessdate=26 May 2016|work=The Globe and Mail| place=Toronto|date=23 October 2014}}</ref> In response to a recommendation that the province add 300 new long-term health care beds for the most severely mentally ill, provincial Health Minister [[Terry Lake]] said that more research was needed to determine whether these beds were urgently needed.<ref name=Woo2014/> As of 2015, the province had opened or committed to only 50 new beds.<ref name="Lupick2015">{{cite news|last1=Lupick|first1=Travis|title=Vancouver hospitals predict 2015 will see emergency mental-health visits surpass 10,000|url=https://www.straight.com/life/510721/vancouver-hospitals-predict-2015-will-see-emergency-mental-health-visits-surpass-10000|accessdate=26 May 2016|work=Georgia Straight| place=Vancouver|date=19 August 2015}}</ref>
==Co-ordination of services== Although DTES residents often have a complex combination of needs, services are typically delivered from the perspective of a single discipline (such as police or medical), or a particular agency's mandate, with little communication between the service providers who are working with a given individual.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=2}} Despite widespread agreement in principle that a co-ordinated approach is necessary to improve conditions for DTES residents, the three levels of government have not agreed on any overall long-term plan for the DTES, and there is no overall co-ordination of services for the area.<ref name=Hopper2014/>
In 2009, the [[Vancouver Police Department|VPD]] proposed the creation of a steering committee made up of senior city and provincial stakeholders, which would be mandated to improve collaboration between service providers to enable a client-centric rather than discipline-centric model.{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|pp=2-3}} The report recommends prioritizing the needs of the most vulnerable individuals in the neighbourhood, saying that having them get the assistance they require is "a necessary condition for other neighbourhood improvement initiatives to succeed."{{sfn|Vancouver Police Department|2009|p=2}}
